questions.text: A male patient presented with itching of the scalp and hair infection. The hair perforation test was positive. Which of the following is the causative organism ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T. Mentagrophytes Positive hair perforation is seen in some dermatophytes, especially T. mentagrophytes. It is also used to differentiate common isolates i.e. T mentagrophytes from T rubrum. Dermatophytosis (tinea) infections are fungal infections caused by dermatophytes - a group of fungi that invade and grow in dead keratin.

Highyeild:

DERMATOPHYTE Affects Macroconidia Microconidia Trichophyton Skin, Hair, Nail Pencil shaped +++ Microsporum Skin, Hair Spindle-shaped ++ Epidermophyton Skin, Nails Club/boat-shaped - Spreads by coming in contact with an infected person or animals Diagnosis: Confirmed by obtaining scales from a lesion and visualizing branching, septate hyphae on a KOH test. Treatment: Topical and systemic antifungals Feet - tinea pedis. Body including trunk and arms - tinea corporis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A and B. Gypseum and B. M. Audonii: These are also dermatophyte fungi that can cause tinea capitis, but they are less common than T. mentagrophytes. They are also less likely to perforate the hair shafts. Option D. Rubrum: It is a common cause of tinea pedis (athlete's foot) and tinea corporis (ringworm), but it is not typically associated with hair infections.

questions.text: A patient presents with paronychia & extensive wheal-like infection pattern (linear) on the upper limb. A suitable antibiotic for treatment?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amoxyclav The given clinical picture is of Acute Paronychia with linear wheal like lesion on the upper limb which is suggestive of Acute lymphangitis. Any focus of infection can spread to lymphatics which is linear. And Amoxyclav is the best suitable antibiotic for this case.

Highyeild:

Paronychia It is inflammation of the skin around a finger or toenail. It can be further divided into Acute paronychia Chronic paronychia Acute paronychia Chronic paronychia <6 weeks persists > 6 weeks Risk factors: ● Onychophagia ● Thumb-sucking ● Post manicure ● Ingrown toenails ● Drugs Risk factors: Occurs in people with hand dermatitis ● Cleaners ● Housewives ● Fisherman ● Dairy handlers Cause: Bacterial infection - S.aureus, S. progenies, Pseudomonas Fungal infection - Candida albicans Virus- Herpes simplex Cause: Often due to infection with Candida albicans Features: ● Develops rapidly ● Usually affect single nail fold ● Pain, redness and swelling present Features: ● Develops gradually ● Nail dystrophy and swelling present Treatment: Warm compress, Topical antiseptics, and oral antibiotics, surgical I&D Treatment: Keep hands dry and warm, emollients, topical corticosteroids, and oral antifungal. In recalcitrant chronic paronychia, en bloc excision of the proximal nail fold is done. Diagnosis Gram staining and/or culture - To help identify a bacterial cause of fluctuant paronychia Potassium hydroxide (KOH) 5% smears - To help diagnose paronychia caused by a candidal infection Tzanck smears - If herpetic whitlow is suspected Classic presentation of paronychia, with erythema and pus surrounding the nail bed.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B. Mikacin: It is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that is primarily used to treat severe bacterial infections, such as sepsis, pneumonia, and urinary tract infections. It is not typically used to treat skin and soft tissue infections. Option C. Norfloxacin: It is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that is commonly used to treat urinary tract infections and some gastrointestinal infections. It is not typically used to treat skin and soft tissue infections. Option D. Metronidazole: It is an antibiotic that is commonly used to treat infections caused by anaerobic bacteria, such as bacterial vaginosis, intra-abdominal infections, and periodontitis. It is not typically used to treat skin and soft tissue infections.

Extraedge:

Anatomy of nail and nail bed

questions.text: A truck driver came with complaints of a painless genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse, motility of the causative organism can be best checked by which type of microscope?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dark field microscope The features described hints towards a diagnosis of syphilis Demonstration of T. palladium from the lesion is the most specific diagnostic test for syphilis Dark Field microscopy : Pallidum appears as a Corkscrew-shaped organism with characteristic movements (especially angulation)

Highyeild:

Syphillis Etiology: Treponema pallidum Incubation period: 9 to 90 days Primary lesion: papules which progress to the genital ulcer (Hard chancre/ hunter Ian chancre) Single ulcer with clean base Induration present Nontender No bleeding on touch Inguinal lymph nodes: Bilaterally enlarged, non-tender, rubbery consistency Diagnosis: Dark field microscopy Secondary syphilis : Symmetric, non-pruritic, polymorphic rash over palms and soles Mucosal lesion: Condyloma Lata Snail liveck ulcer Latent & tertiary Syphilis- Gummatous syphilis: Rubbery nodules breaks to form ulcer. with a punched-out edge. Treatment: Inj. Benzathine penicillin

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B .Electron microscopes: It uses a beam of electrons to magnify the specimen, but they are not typically used to observe live specimens. Option C. Fluorescent microscopes: It uses fluorescent dyes to label specific structures within cells, but they are not typically used to observe liv, motile bacteria. Option D .Light microscopes: It uses visible light to magnify the specimen, but they are not as useful for observing live, unstained bacteria as dark field microscopy.

questions.text: A Migrant labourer came with complaints of urethral discharge after 1 week of unprotected sexual intercourse. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gonorrhoea The given clinical scenario shows thick, profuse, and purulent urethral discharge which are characteristics of Gonococcal urethritis. Gonorrhea: Etiology: Neisseria gonorrhoeae Incubation period: 2 to 5 days Clinical features: Severe dysuria Urethral discharge Constitutional symptoms (fever) Diagnosis: Gram stain- intracellular diplococci Treatment: Uncomplicated gonorrhea (lacks features of PID)= IM ceftriaxone Coinfection with C.Trachomatis = Oral Doxycycline for 7 days

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . E. coli: It can cause urinary tract infections, it is not a common cause of the urethral discharge. Option C . Ureaplasma urealyticum: It is a bacterium that is sometimes associated with non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU), which can cause urethral discharge. But the discharge is watery and not thick and purulent like gonococcal urethritis. Option D. Trichomoniasis : It is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It can cause urethral discharge in both men and women, but it is less common than gonorrhea as a cause of urethral discharge.

questions.text: A patient of 30 years came with Flaccid bullae on her skin which are easy to rupture. The biopsy revealed a Suprabasal split. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

P. vulgaris The given clinical history of flaccid bullae and the suprabasal split is suggestive of Pemphigus Vulgaris. It is an immunobullous disease ( Type 2 hypersensitivity, IgG antibodies ) that commonly present at 40 to 60 years of age. Target protein: Desmosomes Target antigen: DSG3> DSG1 Characteristics: Flaccid bullae with positive bullae spread sign and nikolsky sign. 90 to 95% of patients have oral mucosal lesions Histopathology: Acantholytic cells Suprabasal split Intact basal layer Direct immunofluorescence: Fishnet appearance- Epidermal intercellular deposits of IgG and C3 with a reticular pattern Treatment: High dose systemic steroids, cyclophosphamide, Rituximab

Highyeild:

Direct immunofluorescence findings in common bullous disorders Pemphigus Vulgaris Fishnet appearance- Epidermal intercellular deposits of C3 with a reticular pattern Pemphigus Foliaceous Fishnet appearance Bullous pemphigoid Linear deposits of IgG on the dermal-epidermal junction in bullous pemphigoid Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita Linear deposits of IgG on the dermal-epidermal junction zone, with a u-serrated pattern

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Other Options: Option A . Pemphigus Vegetans: It presents with Tumid, Vegetating hypertrophic plaques in the intertriginous areas. There is also the presence of a Cerebriform tongue. Option C. Pemphigus Foliaceus: It involves the seborrheic areas of the body. There is no oral involvement. Flaccid vesicles are present which have a tendency to heal spontaneously. Option D . Erythema multiforme: It is an immune-mediated, typically self-limiting, mucocutaneous condition characterized by ‘target’ lesions.

questions.text: The girl child was presenting with rough lesions over her elbows, and knees (extensor surface), and also had problems with night vision.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Phrynoderma The given clinical scenario shows follicular hyperkeratosis with problems with night vision (Nyctalopia) is suggestive of Vitamin A deficiency causing Phrynoderma.

Highyeild:

Phrynoderma It is a form of follicular hyperkeratosis associated with nutritional deficiency. Often associated with: Intestinal malabsorption Anorexia nervosa Fad diets Previous bariatric surgery or small bowel bypass surgery A history of alcoholism. Cause: Vitamin A deficiency (commonly) Severe malnutrition Vitamin E and B deficiency Essential fatty acid deficiency. Sites: Elbows, knees, extensor extremities, and/ or buttocks Features: Distribution of lesions is bilateral and symmetrical Follicular papules of various sizes with central keratotic plugs that block the follicle openings develop on the skin. Treatment: Oral vitamin supplements, topical keratolytic agents

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A . Keratosis pilaris: It is a common skin condition with retention of keratin at follicular openings. The condition most commonly presents within the first 2 years of life with affected areas on the cheeks, upper arms, and/or thighs. It is more common in individuals with underlying atopic dermatitis. Dry winter weather and humidity often worsen the condition. Option C . Darier’s disease: It is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder classified as a hereditary acantholytic dermatosis that typically presents with scaly crusted papules in a seborrhoeic distribution and in skin folds. Option D. Folliculitis : It means an inflamed hair follicle due to any cause. The result is a tender red spot, often with a surface pustule.

questions.text: Male child complains of mild painful Boggy swelling in the scalp for 3 months. Pet animals are there at home. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Kerion Kerion is an inflammatory pustular folliculitis involving circumscribed scalp areas presenting as tender boggy swelling.

Highyeild:

FAVUS KERION Yellow cup shard crust seen- scutula Inflamed, Indurated, boggy swelling with hair, and pustules seen. Causative organism - T. Schoenleinii Causative organism - T. Mentagrophytes

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Folliculitis: It means an inflamed hair follicle due to any cause. The result is a tender red spot, often with a surface pustule. Option B. Abscess: It is a localized collection of pus in a cavity formed from tissues that have been broken down by infectious bacteria. Option D. Epidermoid cyst: It is a benign cyst derived from the infundibulum or upper portion of a hair follicle, encapsulated in a thin layer of epidermis-like epithelium. Epidermoid cysts are typically filled with keratin and lipid-rich debris.
